bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Frederick F. Russell, June 5, 1923

div1.p: [Carter] discusses an article by Gouzien. He mentions the outbreaks of yellow fever in Colombia and Venezuela. He anticipates the Health Board's work in Brazil.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Frederick F. Russell, June 5, 1923
div1.opener:
/LC
I.H.B.
Summary
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
June 5, 1923.
Dr. F. F. Russell,
General Director,
International Health Board,
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
Referring to letter of Miss Read of June 1st. with enclosures, I
would say

1/ I had seen Gouzien's article, the translation of a part of
which was enclosed, and spite of the reports of Darling and Noguchi,
which go to show that the diagnosis of yellow fever in the case of
Bradinelli was not justified, it is hard to believe that this mistake
was made in all (37?) of the cases reported in West Africa. Especial-
ly is this true as (a) they were reported from nine different places,
hence by not less than nine physicians, and (b) none had been reported
in this region, I think, since 1918, showing that there was apparently
no undue tendency to find yellow fever.

2/ Until one knows more about the condition in Colombia (and
Venezuela) it is not possible to evaluate the outbreak there. If it
comes to the coast--as one would expect it to do--there would be risk
of its introduction into Mexico and Central America, a thing we would
be loth to have happen. This is the more unfortunate as there is no
other focus of yellow fever which threatens this section. The yel-
low fever on the Venezuelan coast, of course, would threaten Curacao:
Trinidad: Barbadoes and Porto Rico and in the last would be a calamity,
although it would quite certainly be eliminated from all of the four.
four.
2
It died out spontaneously on the Venezuelan coast during the commer-
cial depression of the World War, but would be less apt to do so now
on account of the number of oil men (susceptible) that are scattered
on it. They are dredging out Maracaibo and purpose to make it quite
a port.

It is the introduction of modern methods: increased communication
etc. among backward people which has always spread yellow fever and,
I suppose, other infections.

3/ I hope that work may start as soon as possible in Brazil, es-
pecially at Ceara.

If, as I understood from Hackett, the Brazilianz are expecting
to again begin the rubber collection on the Amazon, it is the people from
Ceara that will be used therein and if Ceara stays infected we will
quite certainly have yellow fever again in this valley.
